statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following} \\ \qquad f(x) = \cos \left(\log x + e^x\right), x\gt 0

step.tex: \cos \left(\log x + e^x\right)\text{ is defined only if }\\ \log x + e^x \text{ is defined.} \\ \text{Now, }e^x\text{ is defined for all x. But }\log x\\ \text{is defined only for }x\gt 0. \\ \text{Hence, for f(x) to be defined, }x\gt 0.
\text{It is not important at all.}x\gt 0\text{ is written}\\ \text{only to confuse us.}

\begin{align} \text{Let }g(x) &= \log x + e^x \\ \implies f(x) &= \cos g(x) \\ \text{and, }\dfrac{dg}{dx} &= \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right) \\ \therefore \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \dfrac{df}{dg} \cdot \dfrac{dg}{dx} \\ &= -\sin g\cdot \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right) \\ &= -\sin (\log x + e^x)\cdot \left(\frac{1}{x} + e^x\right), x \gt 0 \end{align}
step.reason: \text{You would've recognized the above as simply}\\ \text{the application of the }\textbf{Chain Rule.}\\ \text{If }f(x) = u(v(x)),\text{ then }f'x = \frac{du}{dv}\cdot\frac{dv}{dx}.
